commit_message:
Update upgrade role for Queens from P

This changes the a-r-r with the proper version, and fixes
the repo path for role upgrades:

The role will, during test-upgrade-pre, have its current branch
checked out, and will deploy the current branch infrastructure,
including the generation of the constraints.

Then, the installation of previous branch of the role will use
the constraints for its previous version, but will have no
constraints for it, and fail.

We need to generate the constraints for the previous version too.
This should do it.

On top of it, we need to enfore git and iptables to the list of
packages, because of the issues happening in the developer mode:

Error [Errno 2] No such file or directory while executing command
git clone -q https://git.openstack.org/openstack/neutron
  /tmp/pip-build-iS3zW0/neutron
Cannot find command 'git'\n"

This patch also implements an initial set of jobs intended to
match the current job execution method. It does not intend to
improve how the jobs are executed - only to replicate what is
currently in openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs and provide
the platform to iterate on.

To avoid the chicken and egg issue, this patchset temporarily disables
the upgrade testing.

Co-Authored-By: Manuel Buil <mbuil@suse.com>
Change-Id: I48a554e4ef92bc3c156e43881013cc85df0dc8d4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-os_neutron refs/changes/16/511816/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

subject: Handle glance image pagination links better
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-13 21:25:08.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/shade/commit/f901ebbe745631539b88dc05adf27bf430bcb45b', 'message': 'Handle glance image pagination links better

Glance returns pagination links like "/v2/images?marker=". keystoneauth
Adapter treats absolute links like that as if they are rooted on the
service url. Since the catalog has https://image.example.com/v2 in it,
the Adapter will be mounted on that, which means /v2/images will be
treated as "https://image.example.com/v2/v2/iamges - which is not
correct.

Doing a urljoin would also be incorrect in an OpenStack context, because
the service could be on a sub-url, such as https://example.com/image,
meaning the v2 API endpoint would be https://example.com/image/v2 -
which means a straight urljoin of https://example.com/image/v2 and
/v2/images?marker= would result in https://example.com/v2/images?marker=
which is wrong since it strips the /image path prefix.

The most correct things for glance to do would be to return a full
absolute url - or a full relative URL. Constructing the absolute url
shade-side is hard for the above reasons - we don't have the right
context.

Strip /v1/ or /v2/ from the front of the next links (yay!) to turn
it into a relative url - thereby letting adapter.get(endpoint) do the
correct thing.

While doing this, update the catalog fixture in the test suite to have a
trailing /v2 so that we can be sure we're doing the correct thing in our
unit tests.

Change-Id: I6fc8484ed62a029a8ba8ff1d31a37ba69e3000cf

Doing a urljoin would also be incorrect in an OpenStack context, because
the service could be on a sub-url, such as https://example.com/image,

which means a straight urljoin of https://example.com/image/v2 and
/v2/images?marker= would result in https://example.com/v2/images?marker=
which is wrong since it strips the /image path prefix.

The most correct things for glance to do would be to return a full
absolute url - or a full relative URL. Constructing the absolute url
shade-side is hard for the above reasons - we don't have the right
context.

Strip /v1/ or /v2/ from the front of the next links (yay!) to turn
it into a relative url - thereby letting adapter.get(endpoint) do the
correct thing.

While doing this, update the catalog fixture in the test suite to have a
trailing /v2 so that we can be sure we're doing the correct thing in our
unit tests. Also add suburl fixtures to ensure that we work with
suburls.

Change-Id: I6fc8484ed62a029a8ba8ff1d31a37ba69e3000cf
'}]
commit_message:
Handle glance image pagination links better

Glance returns pagination links like "/v2/images?marker=". keystoneauth
Adapter treats absolute links like that as if they are rooted on the
service url. Since the catalog has https://image.example.com/v2 in it,
the Adapter will be mounted on that, which means /v2/images will be
treated as "https://image.example.com/v2/v2/iamges - which is not
correct.

Doing a urljoin would also be incorrect in an OpenStack context, because
the service could be on a sub-url, such as https://example.com/image,
meaning the v2 API endpoint would be https://example.com/image/v2 -
which means a straight urljoin of https://example.com/image/v2 and
/v2/images?marker= would result in https://example.com/v2/images?marker=
which is wrong since it strips the /image path prefix.

The most correct things for glance to do would be to return a full
absolute url - or a full relative URL. Constructing the absolute url
shade-side is hard for the above reasons - we don't have the right
context.

Strip /v1/ or /v2/ from the front of the next links (yay!) to turn
it into a relative url - thereby letting adapter.get(endpoint) do the
correct thing.

While doing this, update the catalog fixture in the test suite to have a
trailing /v2 so that we can be sure we're doing the correct thing in our
unit tests. Also add suburl fixtures to ensure that we work with
suburls.

Change-Id: I6fc8484ed62a029a8ba8ff1d31a37ba69e3000cf
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/shade refs/changes/63/511963/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # next links from glance have the version prefix. If the catalog # has a versioned endpoint, then we can't append the next link to # it. Strip the absolute prefix (/v1/ or /v2/ to turn it into # a proper relative link. if endpoint.startswith('/v'): endpoint = endpoint[4:] response = self._image_client.get(endpoint)
deleted_lines: # Use the raw endpoint from the catalog not the one from # version discovery so that the next links will work right response = self._raw_image_client.get(endpoint)

commit_message:
Do not ignore the QOS options on port update

The qos_options parameter that was being passed by the qos driver on
when calling update_port() in the ml2 driver was being ignored. This
patch is fixing the problem.

Change-Id: I027cc522fbb24e1829afe18cb7485f80b9c5ab55
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-ovn refs/changes/72/512672/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self._ovn_client.update_port(port, original_port, qos_options=qos_options)

Remove legacy template jobs from ansible-role-nodepool

This role no longer will be using legacy jobs, so we can remove them
from project-config.

added_lines: By default, each endpoint is located in the same namespace as the current service's helm chart. To connect to a service which is running in a different kubernetes namespace, a ``namespace`` can be provided to each individual endpoint.

commit_message:
Initial OSA zuul v3 role jobs

This patch implements an initial set of jobs intended to match
the current job execution method. It does not intend to improve
how the jobs are executed - only to replicate what is currently
in openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs and provide the platform
to iterate on.

Change-Id: I3b72774f0859c2453e2f9b219eefbebd4b631108

commit_message:
fix branch handling in release clone_repo function

When no branch is specified, we don't want to include the '--branch'
argument to clone_repo.sh.

Change-Id: Ie9ee423835ba7ba6e8822748db29aeab5b1d31fc
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/14/513014/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Sometimes we aren't given a branch, and when we aren't we don't # want to pass the wrong arguments to clone_repo.sh. if [ ! -z "$branch" ]; then branch_arg="--branch" fi $_functions_bindir/clone_repo.sh $branch_arg $branch $repo

commit_message:
Fix object_client methods to accept headers and query param

Many of the method of object_client accept many headers and
query param.
This commit makes them to accept all headers and query param.

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: I80668c00a38db00958bbe54421e69798d54482d7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tempest refs/changes/73/511173/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: self.object_client.create_or_update_object_metadata( self.container_name, self.object_name, headers=metadata)

Initial OSA zuul v3 role jobs

This patch implements an initial set of jobs intended to match
the current job execution method. It does not intend to improve
how the jobs are executed - only to replicate what is currently
in openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs and provide the platform
to iterate on.

Change-Id: If86f31a6ff188c57c5981dcf9eddc26af7101b25
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-lxc_container_create refs/changes/09/512709/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: export ZUUL_TESTS_CLONE_LOCATION="/home/zuul/src/git.openstack.org/openstack/openstack-ansible-tests"# We only want to use zuul-cloner if we detect # zuul v2 running, so we check for the presence # of the ZUUL_REF environment variable. # ref: http://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack-infra/zuul/tree/zuul/ansible/filter/zuul_filters.py?h=feature/zuulv3#n17 if [[ -x /usr/zuul-env/bin/zuul-cloner ]] && [[ "${ZUUL_REF:-none}" != "none" ]]; then # symlink it. As zuul v3 clones into a folder called # 'workspace' we have to use one of its environment # variables to determine the project name. if [[ "${ZUUL_SHORT_PROJECT_NAME:-none}" == "openstack-ansible-tests" ]] ||\ [[ "$(basename ${WORKING_DIR})" == "openstack-ansible-tests" ]]; then # In zuul v3 any dependent repository is placed into # /home/zuul/src/git.openstack.org, so we check to see # if there is a tests checkout there already. If so, we # symlink that and use it. elif [[ -d "${ZUUL_TESTS_CLONE_LOCATION}" ]]; then ln -s "${ZUUL_TESTS_CLONE_LOCATION}" ${WORKING_DIR}/tests/common # Otherwise we're clearly not in zuul or using a previously setup # repo in some way, so just clone it from upstream.
deleted_lines: if [[ -x /usr/zuul-env/bin/zuul-cloner ]]; then # symlink it. if [[ "$(basename ${WORKING_DIR})" == "openstack-ansible-tests" ]]; then

commit_message:
Correct template names from ocata to pike.

There are still some HOT templates pointing to ocata and
they should be pointing to pike.

This patch needs to be backported to stable/pike.

Change-Id: I42cc7e6d97e1f9d043d3cf82fc164448558d47bd

commit_message:
Initial OSA zuul v3 role jobs

This patch implements an initial set of jobs intended to match
the current job execution method. It does not intend to improve
how the jobs are executed - only to replicate what is currently
in openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs and provide the platform
to iterate on.

Change-Id: I4d74893c21c36042b640acf42457495ad862770e

commit_message:
`cardinality_for` should be be chosen from `source`/`target`

It is easier to implement and understand to use key instead of value

Change-Id: If33f5c316393c48a0555a0fd1c92bd0ccf13f7a2

subject: Implement minor update workflow with config download
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-07-26 15:43:09.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/python-tripleoclient/commit/8dcddf9eb56ccca12438713fcf4d82aa44cb4d38', 'message': 'WIP -- simplify minor workflow

This change aim to refactor the way of doing the minor upgrade
via ansible playbook download by the config download
It will depend on a mistral change which will get the
ansible update_task and run it via mistral
The user will have two ways for performing the minor update:
  - the stack update command which will make an automatic minor
    upgrade (or just upgrade a given set of nodes)
  - running it manually via ansible on the undercloud

commit_message:
Implement minor update workflow with config download

This change aim to refactor the way of doing the minor upgrade
via ansible playbook download by the config download
It will depend on a mistral change which will get the
ansible update_task and run it via mistral
The user will have two ways for performing the minor update:
  - the stack update command which will make an automatic minor
    upgrade (or just upgrade a given set of nodes)
  - running it manually via ansible on the undercloud

Closes-Bug: #1715557
Closes-Bug: #1723108
Change-Id: I4fcd443d975894a1da0286b19506d00682c5768c

deleted_lines: parser.add_argument('stack', nargs='?', default=utils.env('OVERCLOUD_STACK_NAME')) parser.add_argument('-i', '--interactive', dest='interactive', action='store_true') parser.add_argument( '--answers-file', help=_('Path to a YAML file with arguments and parameters. ' 'DEPRECATED. Not necessary when used with a plan. Will ' 'be silently ignored, and removed in the "P" release.') ) if parsed_args.interactive: timeout = 0 status = package_update.update_and_wait( self.log, clients, stack, stack_name, self.app_args.verbose_level, timeout) if status not in ['COMPLETE']: raise exceptions.DeploymentError("Package update failed.") else: package_update.update(clients, container=stack_name, queue_name=str(uuid.uuid4())) print("Package update on stack {0} initiated.".format( parsed_args.stack)) class ClearBreakpointsOvercloud(command.Command): """Clears a set of breakpoints on a currently updating overcloud""" log = logging.getLogger(__name__ + ".ClearBreakpointsOvercloud") def get_parser(self, prog_name): parser = super(ClearBreakpointsOvercloud, self).get_parser(prog_name) parser.add_argument('stack', nargs='?', help=_('Name or ID of heat stack to clear a ' 'breakpoint or set of breakpoints ' '(default=Env: OVERCLOUD_STACK_NAME)'), default=utils.env('OVERCLOUD_STACK_NAME')) parser.add_argument('--ref', action='append', dest='refs', help=_('Breakpoint to clear')) return parser def take_action(self, parsed_args): self.log.debug("take_action(%s)" % parsed_args) clients = self.app.client_manager heat = clients.orchestration stack = oooutils.get_stack(heat, parsed_args.stack) package_update.clear_breakpoints(clients, stack_id=stack.id, refs=parsed_args.refs)

commit_message:
Move the object client to tempest.lib

Move the object client to tempest.lib and cleanup the last bits
of code that were required to manage internal-only tempest service
clients.

Change-Id: Ia9aeab78e530c798dfa7b7d6f71e4b3ea3a84b7f

commit_message:
Create new json exporter

Now the json format which was exported by `rally task results` is too old,
We expect to use `rally task report --json` instead of it.

New json exporter command:
    rally task report --json --uuid <task_uuid> --out <dest_file>
    rally task export --uuid <task_uuid> --type json --to <dest_file>

Change-Id: Idbb20513ec1013d0f2b7a7458dc8bffef4771e84
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/64/479464/37 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: OPTS["task_report"]="--out --open --html --html-static --json --uuid"

subject: Do Not Merge - post zuulv3
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-09-30 14:04:42.000000000', 'files': ['DO-NOT-MERGE-ME'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/manila/commit/f6edda8cd99f25a6461e31562a23663d79d89673', 'message': "Do Not Merge - post zuulv3

Let's see what jobs we need to fix.

commit_message:
Bugfix: fix the auth_version

If the auth_url is "https://192.168.31.222:443/identity-admin/v3", the
auth_version is supposed to be "v3", not "id".

Change-Id: I3aa237d7397a87d103637a2b578fc53fd50d79eb
Signed-off-by: Linda Wang <wangwulin@hotmail.com>
(cherry picked from commit b8bb92e083983ad6a01ab41702846865d2cf2f4d)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/09/513009/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: auth_version = [v for v in url_path.split("/") if v][-1][:2]

commit_message:
Bugfix: fix the auth_version

If the auth_url is "https://192.168.31.222:443/identity-admin/v3", the
auth_version is supposed to be "v3", not "id".

commit_message:
Remove docker.io prefix from ceph_namespace

Prefixing the image url with a custom registry causes the
image prepare command to fail when using --pull-source

Change-Id: I099b5a9600d54dce7c1f994494fb3a7505323886
Closes-Bug: #1724347
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-common refs/changes/03/512803/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: {% set ceph_namespace=ceph_namespace or "ceph" %}

subject: Glare - OpenStack Artifact Service
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-06-30 12:28:16.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/commit/8a397712f912192bf7ba5ab946af93d362c3f900', 'message': "Glare - OpenStack Artifact Service

Glare (from GLare Artifact REpository) is a service that provides
access to a unified catalog of structured meta-information as well
as related binary data (these structures are also called 'artifacts').

Glare aims to respond to community needs and create a unified
repository of artifacts for all types of data. Currently in
OpenStack there is no single solution in this regard: some files
are stored directly in the database, some on github, for Nova they
developed a service called Glance, and so on. Nevertheless, none of
the solutions do not eliminate issues of data immutability, versioning
of artifacts, do not offer a convenient means of storing and searching.
Glare came as an answer to that.

A key feature of the service is the ability to manage different
artifacts of various nature, from the virtual machine and docker images,
to database backups and heat templates. At the same time, no matter what
type of artifact is used - Glare always provides a single universal API
for working with them.
In addition Glare offers plenty innovative, user friendly features:
 * Artifact versioning in SemVer format.
 * Multiple binary objects per entity.
 * Dependencies between artifacts.
 * Advanced sorting and filtering with various operators.
 * Micro version API support.
 * Zero downtime database upgrades.
And many more!

Glare is used in production deployments and has vast adoption as it's
shipped as a part of Nokia CloudBand platform.

The service was presented in Barcelona Summit[1], as well as in demos
at various design sessions.
Glare API and architecture are well documented [2][3].

Glare project strictly follows the Four Opens suggested by OpenStack
Foundation. Glare code has been developed under an Apache 2.0 license.
Bugs are filed, reviewed and tracked in Launchpad [4]. New patches are
submitted and reviewed through OpenStack Gerrit and the project core
team checks all the changes before merging them.

Glare is implemented using libraries and technologies adopted by
OpenStack community such as SQLAlchemy for database interractions,
oslo.versionedobjects for declaring new artifact types, glance_store
for communication with various cloud stores, and mane others.
The project obeys the coordinated interfaces, including tox, pbr,
global-requirements, and so on. Glare gate now runs pep8, py27, py35,
and docs tasks.

Glare has devstack plugin and required tempest test infrastructure. Glare
client provides a cli plugin for openstack client - 'openstack artifact'.

Project team has been using openstack-dev mailing list and freenode IRC
channel #openstack-glare heavily for cooperation. The Glare team is happy
to participate in any goals specified by the TC, and meet any policies
that the TC requires all projects to meet.

In conclusion, Glare fills a real need in OpenStack. Glare offers new
advanced flexible catalog that can support various artifact type
structures, which is currently lacking in OpenStack.
As Glare enhances OpenStack capabilities, raises a lot of interest in the
community, and is developed by OpenStack standards, we believe it should
become an Official Project!

[1] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uBtqdXciF4A&t=294s
[2] https://github.com/openstack/glare/blob/master/doc/source/developer/webapi/v1.rst
[3] https://github.com/openstack/glare/blob/master/doc/source/architecture.rst
[4] https://bugs.launchpad.net/glare

Change-Id: I4acb30085c0fe5023f3eefd8b375b8c210aa4b4f

for communication with various cloud stores, and mane others.
The project obeys the coordinated interfaces, including tox, pbr,
global-requirements, and so on. Glare gate now runs pep8, py27, py35,
and docs tasks.

Glare has devstack plugin and required tempest test infrastructure.
Glare client provides a cli plugin for openstack client named
'openstack artifact'.

Project team has been using openstack-dev mailing list and freenode IRC
channel #openstack-glare heavily for cooperation.

In conclusion, Glare fills a real need in OpenStack. Glare offers new
advanced flexible catalog that can support various artifact type
structures, which is currently lacking in OpenStack.
As Glare enhances OpenStack capabilities, raises a lot of interest in
the community, and is developed by OpenStack standards, we believe it
should become an Official Project!

[1] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uBtqdXciF4A
[2] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/glare/tree/doc/source/developer/webapi/v1.rst
[3] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/glare/tree/doc/source/architecture.rst
[4] https://bugs.launchpad.net/glare

Co-Authored-By: Idan Narotzki <idan.narotzki@nokia.com>

commit_message:
Glare - OpenStack Artifact Service

Glare (from GLare Artifact REpository) is a service that provides
access to a unified catalog of structured meta-information as well
as related binary data (these structures are also called 'artifacts').

Glare aims to create a unified repository of artifacts for all types of
data, because currently in OpenStack there is no service that addresses
issues of data immutability, versioning of artifacts, and offers a
convenient means of storing and searching.

A key feature of the service is the ability to manage different
artifacts of various nature: containers, VNF packages,
database backups, heat templates, and so on. At the same time, no matter
what type of artifact is used - Glare always provides a single universal
API for working with them.
In addition Glare offers plenty innovative, user friendly features:
 * Artifact versioning in SemVer format.
 * Multiple binary objects per entity.
 * Dependencies between artifacts.
 * Advanced sorting and filtering with various operators.
 * Micro version API support.
 * Asynchronous data processing and validation.
 * Zero downtime database upgrades.
And many more!

The service was presented in Barcelona Summit[1], as well as in demos
at various design sessions.
Glare API and architecture are well documented [2][3].

Glare project strictly follows the Four Opens suggested by OpenStack
Foundation. Glare code has been developed under an Apache 2.0 license.
Bugs are filed, reviewed and tracked in Launchpad [4]. New patches are
submitted and reviewed through OpenStack Gerrit and the project core
team checks all the changes before merging them.

Glare is implemented using libraries and technologies adopted by
OpenStack community such as SQLAlchemy for database interractions,
oslo.versionedobjects for declaring new artifact types, glance_store
for communication with various cloud stores, and many others.
The project obeys the coordinated interfaces, including tox, pbr,
global-requirements, and so on. Glare gate now runs pep8, py27, py35,
and docs tasks.

Glare has devstack plugin and required tempest test infrastructure.
Glare client provides a cli plugin for openstack client named
'openstack artifact'.

Project team has been using openstack-dev mailing list and freenode IRC
channel #openstack-glare heavily for cooperation.

In conclusion, Glare fills a real need in OpenStack. Glare offers new
advanced flexible catalog that can support various artifact type
structures, which is currently lacking in OpenStack.
As Glare enhances OpenStack capabilities, raises a lot of interest in
the community, and is developed by OpenStack standards, we believe it
should become an Official Project!

[1] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uBtqdXciF4A
[2] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/glare/tree/doc/source/developer/webapi/v1.rst
[3] https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/glare/tree/doc/source/architecture.rst
[4] https://bugs.launchpad.net/glare

Co-Authored-By: Idan Narotzki <idan.narotzki@nokia.com>

commit_message:
Replace the usage of some aliases in tempest

In tempest, following aliases have been moved in version Pike
and will be removed in version Queens:ad
* manager > os_primary [1]
* admin_manager > os_admin [2]
* os_adm > os_admin [3]
* os > os_primary [4]
* alt_manager > os_alt [5]

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/468036/
[2] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/467852/
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/467605/
[4] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/466991/
[5] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/457555/

Change-Id: I2afb94d4f4fcdda1b88ebd90a80c24cfa36f110b

commit_message:
Fix WSGI application

* Partial revert of 0a82af18abbf070a058cb757af68926f9b66798f
  to restore main() method
* Add global `application` variable which will be set by main method to
  problem to preserve the fix from 0a82af18abbf070a058cb757af68926f9b66798f.
* Add check for application name starting with '_mod_wsgi' to ensure
  application runs in Devstack as well (Devstack does not use the entry point)
* Modify Devstack plugin to run WSGI entry point rather than app/wsgi.py from
  module directory.

Change-Id: I07001dccb663ed4e6e3347089ab96e6f8ec196d4
Story: 2001197
Task: 5702

deleted_lines: base_dir = '/etc/monasca/' conf = '%slog-api-paste.ini' % base_dir application = deploy.loadapp('config:%s' % conf)

commit_message:
[WIP] Set lease state fields

Lease objects have three state fields: action, status, and status
reason. However, none of these were set by the manager.

The manager now updates these fields throughout the lifetime of a lease.

Change-Id: Ifa76895d10ab375170ffcb4d999425f11aee14ed

commit_message:
Drop group comparison from drop_privileges test

Drop the group comparison from drop_privileges test as it isn't
valid since os.setgroups() is mocked.

Change-Id: Ida15e72ae4ecdc2d6ce0d37bd99c2d86bd4e5ddc
Closes-Bug: #1724342

commit_message:
Modernize set_vm_state_and_notify

This cleans up several TODOs in the conductor manager
code which calls scheduler_utils.set_vm_state_and_notify
and does mangling of the RequestSpec to make sure it's
a primitive by the time it gets to set_vm_state_and_notify.
That is abstracted in set_vm_state_and_notify itself now.

While doing this, we also remove some translation markers,
update the docs and fix some alignment issues.

Part of blueprint request-spec-use-by-compute

Change-Id: Ibc44e3b2261b314bb92062a88ca9ee6b81298dc3

commit_message:
Make etree.tostring() emit unicode everywhere

etree.tostring() returns bytes by default in python3, and a string by
default in python2. For sanity, we make it explicitly emit unicode
everywhere. This requires a python2 fix in guest, as the libvirt
bindings for python2 don't accept a unicode string to migrateToURI3()'s
'param' argument, whereas the python3 bindings do.

Change-Id: I85cd9a903fba310b5ae7bedeed118ca4ea98dff6

subject: Update "SHUTOFF" description in API guide
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-09 21:14:29.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/a0bf1bc23303a5707bac9834d1db19c15d882bb4', 'message': 'Update "SHUTOFF" description in API guide

Two things are updated here:

1. The SHUTOFF status from the API is for any stopped server,
   regardless of whether or not it was stopped via the REST API
   or the sync_instance_power_state periodic task in the compute.

2. Remove the mention of the "shutdown_terminate" flag since that
   was only ever implemented in the legacy v2 API for EC2
   compatibility and it wouldn't actually work now with the v2.1
   server create schema anyway.

Change-Id: I97071be164d15298fa2a5a7374a8ba8235d188e4
Related-Bug: #1722403

   regardless of whether or not it was stopped via the REST API
   or the sync_instance_power_state periodic task in the compute.

2. Remove the mention of the "shutdown_terminate" flag since that

commit_message:
Update "SHUTOFF" description in API guide

Two things are updated here:

1. The SHUTOFF status from the API is for any stopped server,
   regardless of whether or not it was stopped via the REST API
   or the sync_instance_power_state periodic task in the compute.

2. Remove the mention of the "shutdown_terminate" flag since that
   was only ever implemented in the legacy v2 API for EC2
   compatibility and it wouldn't actually work now with the v2.1
   server create schema anyway.

Change-Id: I97071be164d15298fa2a5a7374a8ba8235d188e4
Related-Bug: #1722403
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/97/510697/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - ``SHUTOFF``: The server was powered down by the user, either through the OpenStack Compute API or from within the server. For example, the user issued a ``shutdown -h`` command from within the server. If the OpenStack Compute manager detects that the VM was powered down, it transitions the server to the SHUTOFF status.
deleted_lines: - ``SHUTOFF``: The server was powered down by the user, but not through the OpenStack Compute API. For example, the user issued a ``shutdown -h`` command from within the server. If the OpenStack Compute manager detects that the VM was powered down, it transitions the server to the SHUTOFF status. If you use the OpenStack Compute API to restart the server, it might be deleted first, depending on the value in the *``shutdown_terminate``* database field on the Instance model.

commit_message:
api-ref: fix server status values in GET /servers docs

The server status values exposed out of the API and used
for filtering when listing instances comes from the values
in nova.api.openstack.common._STATE_MAP. Some of the values
listed in the docs were incorrectly using variable names from
the code, which don't necessarily match the actual value exposed
out of the API.

The compute API server concepts guide actually had this all
correct, so this just updates the API reference.

Change-Id: I30b6f27c6e7fc9365c203b620b311785f8b4b489
Closes-Bug: #1722403

commit_message:
Remove wrapper methods from object_client

There are few methods in object_clients which are
wrapper on PUT API with different combination of
headers.

As object_client is going to be declared as lib interface
it is better to remove these wrapper.

NOTE: Those methods are not being used outside of Tempest.

Partially implements blueprint consistent-service-method-names

Change-Id: Ia70ef3913c1650fad7b8f6b9019378b074c88155

commit_message:
Remove unnecessary BDM destroy during instance delete

Since Ida66a93031046bafcf30c95ca232fb6382c2597b, which was included in
Newton, the BDM is cascade deleted when the instance is deleted so BDM
does not need to be explicity destroyed during instance deletion.

Change-Id: Ia2be0150b5272aaaedbf528d08bbb73ef132d426

commit_message:
Add patch to avoid test failure on no-network envs

The SUSE CI runs without network access to the outside, which
caused tests to fail. add a patch that mocks HTTP calls instead.

Change-Id: If581bc7efb71baa10e700fa8b47fc4c8e0609dcf
(cherry picked from commit ae1e3ab8a7022d32ad9b80ac6cf2b5ad6aa1dcdc)

Mocking the HTTP calls instead helps getting this pass. commit_message:
Migrate to Zuulv3

- Move legacy job to python-zunclient repo.
- Use generic user $USER: Zuul v2 uses 'jenkins' as user, but Zuul v3 uses
  'zuul'.

Change-Id: I7f1a123d1c243bf0f2f53b51671c75c3d01aae68

commit_message:
Fix compatibility with latest OpenStack

* [osclients] do not always strip auth_url

  - add check that version suffix is presented in the auth_url of keystone
    before trying to crop it.
  - port devstack plugin to use AUTH_URL env variable

  Original patch(s): Ib3c56ad0f945787d4df49308deb08bc87199c546

* The latest ansible package is incompatible with os-faults package, so
  we need to bump os-faults version to 0.1.15 where the proper
  requirements of ansible is configured

  Oririnal patch(s): I01a97f6fa315d17ac42af4e7635a0bd0df745795
                     Ica280babc583219eeee0de9a31a4e184a8eb0a0f

* Keystone Tempest plugins moved to separate repo, so we need to use the
  proper url in our verification CI

  Original patch(s): Ie632c55976bcae98c162bdb093184b4c71bad1b5

* Usage of the latest u-c file of OpenStack is hardcoded in tox.ini . It
  means that the latest versions of packages will be installed instead
  of those one which are described in our requirements.txt
  NOTE: it is a fix for only unit and functional tests

* dsvm jobs continue using u-c file. It contains at least one broken
  dependency (python-novaclient).

  - osresources should ignore calling all network API throw the novaclient
    if the neutron is enabled

  - external_network_exists is ported to call nova network API only if
    nova-net is available

* Remove Cinder v1 workload from Cinder gate, since Cinder V1 is not
  available any more.

  Original patch(s): I387da0dd51922c8a3433e2ef3ed78e254cb20172

* Remove testing Nova's image and net API

  Original patch(s): Id5bec277736380343270d3518b0b400efc255d9a
                     Idafbdedaf01c9ed77cf5ec269b0ccf0c90183566

* Fix image type from qcow to the right one ("raw") for one of Cinder's
  workload at CI.

  Original patch(s): I8af9774a2276af66536807f5fd4f8ec392d44f87

* Do not call novaclient for neutron stuff in users@openstack context.

  Original patch(s): Idafbdedaf01c9ed77cf5ec269b0ccf0c90183566

* Add dirty workarounds in cleanup to fix gates

NOTE: since this branch exists only in maintainence mode, test coverage
  is not so important.

Change-Id: I1d66c306318a3de5612d4157de634c136e33b1c5

commit_message:
Allow authentification method to be chosen

To reach Cloudkitty API endpoints, an authentification method must be set.
No authentification or Keystone authentification are allowed.
This should be set in the configuration file, within the DEFAULT block,
using the auth_strategy field.

Task: 4902
Story: 2001168

Change-Id: I3f9d5700e4c2d1a69b5514fd9932a62238ee659c

git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/karbor refs/changes/29/508529/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from io import BytesIO import osfrom karbor.services.protection.bank_plugin import BankIOdef backup_image_to_bank(glance_client, image_id, bank_section, object_size): image_response = glance_client.images.data(image_id, do_checksum=True) bank_chunk_num = int(object_size / 65536) image_chunks_num = 0 chunks_num = 1 image_response_data = BytesIO() for chunk in image_response: image_response_data.write(chunk) image_chunks_num += 1 if image_chunks_num == bank_chunk_num: image_chunks_num = 0 image_response_data.seek(0, os.SEEK_SET) data = image_response_data.read(object_size) bank_section.update_object("data_" + str(chunks_num), data) image_response_data.truncate(0) image_response_data.seek(0, os.SEEK_SET) chunks_num += 1 image_response_data.seek(0, os.SEEK_SET) data = image_response_data.read() if data != '': bank_section.update_object("data_" + str(chunks_num), data) else: chunks_num -= 1 return chunks_num def restore_image_from_bank(glance_client, bank_section, restore_name): resource_definition = bank_section.get_object('metadata') image_metadata = resource_definition['image_metadata'] objects = [key.split("/")[-1] for key in bank_section.list_objects() if (key.split("/")[-1]).startswith("data_")] chunks_num = resource_definition.get("chunks_num", 0) if len(objects) != int(chunks_num): raise Exception("The chunks num of restored image is invalid") sorted_objects = sorted(objects, key=lambda s: int(s[5:])) image_data = BankIO(bank_section, sorted_objects) disk_format = image_metadata["disk_format"] container_format = image_metadata["container_format"] image = glance_client.images.create( disk_format=disk_format, container_format=container_format, name=restore_name ) glance_client.images.upload(image.id, image_data) image_info = glance_client.images.get(image.id) if image_info.checksum != image_metadata["checksum"]: raise Exception("The checksum of restored image is invalid") return image_info

Iscsid is not only needed by cinder lvm backend, but also by ironic
conductor container.

commit_message:
Target context for build notification in conductor

When sending notifications about an instance, it's possible the
notification payload will have attributes not already loaded on
the instance. In this case, a lazy-load will happen and if the
load method needs to lookup the instance (example: in the
_check_instance_exists_in_project method in the DB layer), the
InstanceNotFound exception will be raised and the notification
will fail to be sent.

This targets the instance context to the instance's cell when
calling the send notification method.

Closes-Bug: #1721670

Change-Id: I6b9eb120b6e7fcbf919a3791afe2d1f6a7bd3b60
(cherry picked from commit 54cf9f5a90d745896d133669e6d1260e6adee51b)

commit_message:
event: move models out of storage

There is no more storage in event, and the models are used just to manipulate
Event objects, so let's move it out of this folder.

Change-Id: I43c34857518e5e71728c63f20e10508e5d1dd8d7

commit_message:
pipeline: remove polling fallback support

This removes the support for loading configuration of polling from the
pipeline.

Change-Id: I9f26f9d665a942b91191bbef5ed3e082b4fbf97b
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/ceilometer refs/changes/97/511897/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- upgrade: - | The deprecated support of configure polling in the `pipeline.yaml` file has been removed. Ceilometer now only uses the `polling.yaml` file for polling configuration.

commit_message:
Dummy DB: make unique_key accessible through get_key

Patch [1] added requirement to standardize unique_key access, this patch
adds this to dummy database driver.

[1] 444d23ea3ec74d5dd48b911a09843cdc9407d006

Change-Id: I4249768c59ae5b2b617e1c2d73aecadf27582436
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/dragonflow refs/changes/24/508724/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from dragonflow.db import db_common unique_key_table = self._db[db_common.UNIQUE_KEY_TABLE] unique_key = unique_key_table.get(table, 0) + 1 unique_key_table[table] = unique_key
deleted_lines: self._unique_keys = collections.defaultdict(int) unique_key = self._unique_keys[table] + 1 self._unique_keys[table] = unique_key

commit_message:
Remove zuul-cloner usage from zuul v3 builds

It is now not required to use the zuul-cloner as the required projects
are declared in the zuul config file.
Do not clone the projects, but still install them so they are usable.

Co-Authored-By: Shachar Snapiri <shachar.snapiri@huawei.com>
Change-Id: I3116864d109d98c401c870f97ddcac8e35474580
Depends-On: I581b02cb34602cc9466e9a121544a4e3a36d8e3d

added_lines: #${DIR}/tox_install_project.sh neutron neutron $* #${DIR}/tox_install_project.sh networking-sfc networking_sfc $*

commit_message:
Add dev mode for Neutron

Allows users to develop on Neutron using Kolla.

Change-Id: I13e75f9ea3c353ee27ce6bc8bee92957c746abfb
Partially-Implements: blueprint mount-sources
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/47/507547/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Ceilometer: remove legacy-ceilometer-dsvm-tempest-plugin-es job

Ceilometer does not support ES anymore for a long time now. Moved to Panko.
This job is not used anymore.

Change-Id: I5f52f57d1050d338b54e94b74859b274349ce9cc

commit_message:
Fix 'cover' tox job fails for option --coverage not recognized

When running command tox -ecover, tox job will fail. the error message is

======================================================================
FAIL: process-returncode
tags: worker-0
----------------------------------------------------------------------
returncode 1
Ran 733 (+17) tests in 856.852s (+164.804s)
FAILED (id=6, failures=2, skips=7)
error: testr failed (1)
ERROR: InvocationError: '/home/github/mistral/.tox/py27/bin/python setup.py test
_____________________________________________________ summary __________________
ERROR:   py27: commands failed

Change-Id: I21a335992683aa94d2cf47c4a4fc0f43849dec9a
Closes-bug: #1724121
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/qinling refs/changes/64/512464/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: setenv = {[testenv]setenv} PYTHON=coverage run --source qinling --parallel-mode commands = stestr run {posargs} coverage combine coverage html -d cover coverage xml -o cover/coverage.xml

commit_message:
Add support for ceph-mon bootstrap

Add new relation to support bootstrapping a new deployment
of the ceph-mon charm from an existing ceph charm deployment,
supporting migration away from the deprecated ceph charm.

Each member of the existing ceph application will present
the required fsid and monitor-secret values, as well as its
public address so that the related ceph-mon units can
correctly seed from the exisitng MON cluster.

Provide stop hook implementation, which will leaves OSD
services running but will remove the ceph.conf provided
directly from this charm, falling back to ceph.conf provided
by other charms installed on the same machine. MON and MGR
services will be shutdown and disabled.

Closes-Bug: 1665159

Change-Id: I9bd1d7630a8eff53c65cb0f07d17e095fc7f32a9
Depends-On: Iac34d1bee4b51b55dfb3d14d315aae8526a0893c

commit_message:
Update upgrade role for Queens from P

This changes the a-r-r with the proper version, and fixes
the repo path for role upgrades:

The role will, during test-upgrade-pre, have its current branch
checked out, and will deploy the current branch infrastructure,
including the generation of the constraints.

Then, the installation of previous branch of the role will use
the constraints for its previous version, but will have no
constraints for it, and fail.

We need to generate the constraints for the previous version too.
This should do it.

On top of that, we needed to update the work for Zuul v3:
This implements the initial OSA zuul v3 role jobs.

This patch implements an initial set of jobs intended to match
the current job execution method. It does not intend to improve
how the jobs are executed - only to replicate what is currently
in openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs and provide the platform
to iterate on.

Change-Id: I2d455e9a47c85b77655e3b55847cf45959901b77

commit_message:
Move glance auth cache creation to configure_glance

We install the glance api on all nodes in multinode testing. This has
been failing because we don't configure the glance auth cache dirs if
we only install the glance api service. This was done as part of
init_glance which is only run when installing g-reg.

Fix this by moving the auth cache dir creation step into
configure_glance which is run for the glance api.

Change-Id: Ie669827507df0f524e6e53fe4ab3dff848dd4bd7
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/69/509669/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

The api # Server is configured through this function and not init_glance. create_glance_cache_dir # create_glance_cache_dir() - Part of the configure_glance() process

commit_message:
Implement Database publisher to replace correalted dispatcher

Ceilometer collector has been removed and we need publiser instead
of dispatcher to push data to database backend. So database should
be deprecated and use publisher to replace and keep CI tests work well.

Change-Id: I9fc2fae83b2525499db3abfaba66e529eaee9937

commit_message:
Add Appendix A for Ceph Charm Migration

Add new appendix for migration of legacy ceph charm deployments
to the preferred ceph-mon/ceph-osd deployment architecture.

Change-Id: Iac34d1bee4b51b55dfb3d14d315aae8526a0893c
Related-Bug: 1665159
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/charm-deployment-guide refs/changes/61/505161/3 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Appendix A: Ceph Charm Migration ================================ In order to continue to recieve updates to newer Ceph versions, and for general improvements and features in the charms to deploy Ceph, users of the ceph charm should migrate existing sevices to using ceph-mon and ceph-osd. .. note:: This example migration assumes that the ceph charm is deployed to machines 0, 1 and 2 with the ceph-osd charm deployed to other machines within the model. Deploy ceph-mon ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ First deploy the ceph-mon charm; if the existing ceph charm is deployed to machines 0, 1 and 2, you can place the ceph-mon units in LXD containers on these machines: .. code:: bash juju deploy --to lxd:0 ceph-mon juju config ceph-mon no-bootstrap=True juju add-unit --to lxd:1 ceph-mon juju add-unit --to lxd:2 ceph-mon These units will install ceph, but will not bootstrap into a running monitor cluster. Bootstrap ceph-mon from ceph ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Next, we'll use the existing ceph application to bootstrap the new ceph-mon units: .. code:: bash juju add-relation ceph ceph-mon Once this process has completed, you should have a Ceph MON cluster of 6 units; this can be verified on any of the ceph or ceph-mon units: .. code:: bash sudo ceph -s Deploy ceph-osd to ceph units ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ In order to retain any running Ceph OSD processes on the ceph units, the ceph-osd charm must be deployed to the existing machines running the ceph units: .. code:: bash juju config ceph-osd osd-reformat=False juju add-unit --to 0 ceph-osd juju add-unit --to 1 ceph-osd juju add-unit --to 2 ceph-osd The charm installation and configuration will not impact any existing running Ceph OSD's. Relate ceph-mon to all ceph clients ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ The new ceph-mon units now need to be related to the ceph-osd application: .. code:: bash juju add-relation ceph-mon ceph-osd and depending on your deployment you'll also need to add relations for other applications, for example: .. code:: bash juju add-relation ceph-mon cinder-ceph juju add-relation ceph-mon glance juju add-relation ceph-mon nova-compute juju add-relation ceph-mon ceph-radosgw juju add-relation ceph-mon gnocchi once hook execution completes across all units, each client should be configured with 6 MON addresses. Remove the ceph application ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ Its now safe to remove the ceph application from your deployment: .. code:: bash juju remove-application ceph As each unit of the ceph application is destroyed, its stop hook will remove the MON process from the Ceph cluster monmap and disable Ceph MON and MGR processes running on the machine; any Ceph OSD processes remain untouched and are now owned by the ceph-osd units deployed alongside ceph.

commit_message:
Add documentation for different modes of testing in single task
Delete 'Mode' from glossary
Change-Id: I423e623f6b7a787a9b13a4b75be90190f9f43c4f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/49/355049/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: Different modes in a single task -------------------------------- Rally allows to test cloud in different modes (performance testing, stability testing, capacity testing), modes can be specified in input task. The first step of using modes is determining which modes are necessary for specific cloud. For example, it can be smoke (verify that tests will be executed without errors), performance and stability. The second step is determining the list of scenarios, variables, constants and macros for each mode. There is possible to create macros that contain formulas for times and concurrency in runners for calculating test loads based on numbers of tenants, users, etc. . Formulas can be different for runners of different groups of scenarios (services like authenticate, cinder, nova, neutron, etc.) and modes. You can create task arguments files for each mode with necessary contexts (variables, constants, list of services, number of tenants, number of parallel action per tenant, etc). So you can define task contexts as macro or specify numbers of users, tenants, users per tenant in variables in task file or in task arguments file. In task file scenarios for each mode should be placed in separate if-endif block. The example of task file with smoke, performance and stability modes, macros and some default values is below. For performance mode for every service was created formulas in macro for runners based on numbers of tenants, users, vm per user and parallel actions per tenant. For smoke and stability modes created macros with constant values. .. code-block:: yaml {% set users_per_tenant = users_per_tenant|default(5) %} {% set tenants = tenants|default(10) %} {% set vms_per_user = vms_per_user|default(3) %} {% set parallel_actions_per_tenant = parallel_actions_per_tenant|default(5) %} {%- macro smoke_defaults() %} runner: type: "constant" times: 1 concurrency: 1 context: {} sla: failure_rate: max: 0 max_seconds_per_iteration: 150 {%- endmacro %} {%- macro stability_defaults() %} runner: type: "constant_for_duration" duration: 14400 concurrency: 1 context: {} sla: failure_rate: max: 0 max_seconds_per_iteration: 900 {%- endmacro %} {%- macro runner_performance_authenticate(tenants, users_per_tenant, parallel_actions_per_tenant) %} type: "constant" times: {{ tenants * users_per_tenant * parallel_actions_per_tenant}} concurrency: {{ tenants * parallel_actions_per_tenant}} {%- endmacro %} {%- macro runner_performance_nova_vm(tenants, users_per_tenant, vms_per_user, parallel_actions_per_tenant) %} type: "constant" times: {{ tenants * users_per_tenant * vms_per_user * parallel_actions_per_tenant}} concurrency: {{ tenants * parallel_actions_per_tenant}} {%- endmacro %} --- {% if mode == "smoke" %} Authenticate.keystone: - {{ smoke_defaults() }} NovaServers.boot_and_delete_server: - args: { … } {{ smoke_defaults() }} {% endif %} {% if mode == "performance" %} {% if "authentication" in service_list %} Authenticate.keystone: - runner: {{ runner_performance_authenticate(tenants, users_per_tenant, parallel_actions_per_tenant) }} context: { … } {% endif %} {% if "nova" in service_list %} NovaServers.boot_and_delete_server: - args: { … } runner: {{ runner_performance_nova_vm(tenants, users_per_tenant, vms_per_user, parallel_actions_per_tenant) }} context: { … } {% endif %} --- {% if mode == "stability" %} {% if "authentication" in service_list %} Authenticate.keystone: - runner: {{ stability_defaults() }} context: { … } {% endif %} {% if "nova" in service_list %} NovaServers.boot_and_delete_server: - args: { … } runner: {{ stability_defaults() }} context: { … } {% endif %} {% endif %} Task arguments files (you can redefine some variables here if it is necessary for testing in specific mode): For smoke mode (as an example *task_arguments_smoke.yaml*): .. code-block:: yaml --- tenants: 1 service_list: - authentication - nova For performance mode (*task_arguments_performance.yaml*): .. code-block:: yaml --- tenants: <for example 50 for performance testing> service_list: - authentication - nova For stability mode (*task_arguments_stability.yaml*): .. code-block:: yaml --- service_list: - authentication - nova For example, you want to make some smoke testing before performance and stability test load. The command for first (smoke) running should be .. code-block:: console $ rally task start task_name.yaml --task-args '{"mode": “smoke"}' --task-args-file task_arguments_smoke.yaml For different modes there is necessary to set name of mode and corresponding task args file: .. code-block:: console $ rally task start task_name.yaml --task-args '{"mode": “performance"}' --task-args-file task_arguments_performance.yaml .. code-block:: console $ rally task start task_name.yaml --task-args '{"mode": “stability"}' --task-args-file task_arguments_stability.yaml So Rally gives possibilities to test cloud in different modes with different types of load and provides flexible and simple tools for it.

commit_message:
Make Credential class plugin based

Add base plugin-based Credential class.
Add child class for OpenStack Credentials.
Implements specs/in-progress/deployment_type: steps 5-8.

Change-Id: I74a5db3fa16a4b34cf3758cb3c5ec81d4b89d2fb

deleted_lines: # Copyright 2014: Mirantis Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from rally import consts class Credential(object): def __init__(self, auth_url, username, password, tenant_name=None, permission=consts.EndpointPermission.USER, region_name=None, endpoint_type=consts.EndpointType.PUBLIC, domain_name=None, endpoint=None, user_domain_name="Default", admin_domain_name="Default", project_domain_name="Default", https_insecure=False, https_cacert=None): self.auth_url = auth_url self.username = username self.password = password self.tenant_name = tenant_name self.permission = permission self.region_name = region_name self.endpoint_type = endpoint_type self.domain_name = domain_name self.user_domain_name = user_domain_name self.admin_domain_name = admin_domain_name self.project_domain_name = project_domain_name self.endpoint = endpoint self.insecure = https_insecure self.cacert = https_cacert def to_dict(self, include_permission=False): dct = {"auth_url": self.auth_url, "username": self.username, "password": self.password, "tenant_name": self.tenant_name, "region_name": self.region_name, "endpoint_type": self.endpoint_type, "domain_name": self.domain_name, "endpoint": self.endpoint, "https_insecure": self.insecure, "https_cacert": self.cacert, "user_domain_name": self.user_domain_name, "admin_domain_name": self.admin_domain_name, "project_domain_name": self.project_domain_name} if include_permission: dct["permission"] = self.permission return dct

commit_message:
Add Image content upload context

Add image content customizer. He was needed to upload files from the
local file system into the image and install at it given packages.

It implement abstract method _customize_image the is customize image
in a few steps:
  * boot Nova instance from the image
  * connect to it through ssh client
  * install packages by CloudInit on the image and upload given files
    into the instance
  * Stop the instance and make snapshot of it. Save it into the
    self.context["tenant"]["custom_image"]

Change-Id: I8601ebee1bfaee3596c515bbde55ca28584088f0
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/31/266531/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: # Copyright 2015: Mirantis Inc. # All Rights Reserved. # # Licensed under the Apache License, Version 2.0 (the "License"); you may # not use this file except in compliance with the License. You may obtain # a copy of the License at # # http://www.apache.org/licenses/LICENSE-2.0 # # Unless required by applicable law or agreed to in writing, software # distributed under the License is distributed on an "AS IS" BASIS, WITHOUT # WARRANTIES OR CONDITIONS OF ANY KIND, either express or implied. See the # License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations # under the License. from rally.common import logging from rally.common import sshutils from rally.plugins.openstack.context.vm import custom_image from rally.task import context LOG = logging.getLogger(__name__) @context.configure(name="image_content_customizer", order=520) class ImageContentUpload(custom_image.BaseCustomImageGenerator): """Base class for the contexts providing customized image with. Every context class for the specific customization must implement the method `_customize_image` that is able to connect to the server using SSH and e.g. install applications inside it. This is used e.g. to install the benchmark application using SSH access. This base context class provides a way to prepare an image with custom preinstalled applications. Basically, this code boots a VM, calls the `_customize_image` and then snapshots the VM disk, removing the VM afterwards. The image UUID is stored in the user["custom_image"]["id"] and can be used afterwards by scenario. """ def _customize_image(self, server, ip, user): """Customizes image. :param server: nova.Server instance :param ip: dict with server IP details :param user: user who started a VM instance. Used to extract keypair """ ssh = sshutils.SSH( user, server["ip"], port=self.config["port"], pkey=user["keypair"], password=self.config["password"]) for path in self.config.get("upload"): local_path = path[0] remote_path = path[1] ssh.put_file(local_path, remote_path)

commit_message:
Fix to update Rally Concepts Documentation

Rally Concepts documentation still refers to the old benchmark
framework. It needs to be updated for the new Rally Task
Framework.

Change-Id: I696b45d9e59f187fcf7101fdb9d2036c9a72f076
Closes-Bug: #1503144
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/97/240197/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: From the developer's perspective, a benchmark scenario is a method marked by a **@scenario** decorator and placed in a class that inherits from the base `Scenario <https://github.com/openstack/rally/blob/master/rally/rally/task/scenario.py>`_ class and located in some subpackage of `rally.plugins.openstack.scenarios <https://github.com/openstack/rally/tree/master/rally/plugins/openstack/scenarios>`_. There may be arbitrary many benchmark scenarios in a scenario class; each of them should be referenced to (in the task configuration file) as *ScenarioClassName.method_name*. In a toy example below, we define a scenario class *MyScenario* with one benchmark scenario *MyScenario.scenario*. This benchmark scenario tests the performance of a sequence of 2 actions, implemented via private methods in the same class. Both methods are marked with the **@atomic.action_timer** decorator. This allows Rally to handle those actions in a special way and, after benchmarks complete, show runtime statistics not only for the whole scenarios, but for separate actions as well. from rally.task import scenario from rally.task import atomic # OpenStack scenario has different base now: # rally.plugins.openstack.scenario.OpenStackScenario class MyScenario(scenario.Scenario): @atomic.action_timer("action_1") @atomic.action_timer("action_2") @scenario.configure()It is possible to extend Rally with new Scenario Runner types, if needed. Basically, each scenario runner should be implemented as a subclass of the base `ScenarioRunner <https://github.com/openstack/rally/blob/master/rally/task/runner.py#L113>`_ class and located in the `rally.plugins.common.runners package <https://github.com/openstack/rally/tree/master/rally/plugins/common/runners>`_. The interface each scenario runner class should support is fairly easy:

In a toy example below, we define a scenario class *MyScenario* with one benchmark scenario *MyScenario.scenario*. This benchmark scenario tests the performance of a sequence of 2 actions, implemented via private methods in the same class. Both methods are marked with the **@atomic_action_timer** decorator. This allows Rally to handle those actions in a special way and, after benchmarks complete, show runtime statistics not only for the whole scenarios, but for separate actions as well. from rally.task.scenarios import base from rally.task import utils class MyScenario(base.Scenario): @base.atomic_action_timer("action_1") @base.atomic_action_timer("action_2") @base.scenario()It is possible to extend Rally with new Scenario Runner types, if needed. commit_message:
[cli] Remove duplication of deployment arg

Most of rally commands have equal "--deployment" arguments. This patch
removes code duplication and moves creation of this argument to separate
method.

Change-Id: I8fe2f0249322c4c8b525ba64fa8c4d53eb772883

commit_message:
Change assertTrue(isinstance()) by optimal assert

Some of tests use different method of assertTrue(isinstance(A, B)) or
assertEqual(type(A), B). The correct way is to use assertIsInstance(A,
B) provided by testtools.

Change-Id: I545e006c18b04ad13745b9cac5227880ea411a46
Closes-bug: #1268480

commit_message:
[Spec] Rally upgrades

Change-Id: Ic47d07f51960d322842b6d59c8b8fb57581ade02
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/19/167319/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: =================== Database migrations =================== This describes rally database migrations management and implementation. Problem description =================== We require possibility to create database once and keep it and all the data available for further rally versions. This must be managed via simple CLI, with minimum user efforts. Proposed change =============== Implement database versions management based on `alembic <https://pypi.python.org/pypi/alembic>`_ package and *rally-manage* CLI tool. New files --------- .. code-block:: # This is alembic configuration file, which is required for usage # alembic via cli, however I believe this file will not exist and # all required configuration can be added to rally configuration file # as [alembic] section, so migrations can be invoked via rally cli only rally/alembic.ini # This is a base directory for alembic stuff, especially migrations # There is no __init__.py here, so this is not a package rally/db/migration/ |-- env.py |-- README.rst | | # That is a place for alembic migrations files `--+-- versions/ |-- 3a131dbd91b2_v003_migration.py |-- 7b152ebf94c3_v004_migration.py `-- ... # This module servers migrations, for example here is a place # where alembic migrations hashes are mapped to rally versions, # like this: # # versions = ( # ("3a131dbd91b2", "0.0.3"), # ("7b152ebf94c3", "0.0.4"), # ) rally/db/migration.py Applying migrations ------------------- If rally database version requires update, then *rally* CLI must display proper error message and exit. Version check and running migrations can be done via *rally-manage db* command. Here are some CLI user cases examples: .. code-block:: $ rally task start tasks/my_task.json Current database version is {{rally-old-version}} Update is required to version {{rally-cur-version}} For update, run `rally-manage db version_update' For help, run `rally-manage db --help' # Check version - success $ rally-manage db version_check Current database version is {{rally-cur-version}} Database is up-to-date! # Check version - failure $ rally-manage db version_check Current database version is {{rally-old-version}} Update is required to version {{rally-cur-version}} For update, run `rally-manage db version_update' # Update database version $ rally-manage db version_update {{here is alembic migrations output}} Database has been successfully updated to recent version {{rally-cur-version}}! How does this work ================== Adding new migration -------------------- In case if rally database requires update, developer must: * create and commit new migration file to *rally/db/migration/versions/* * append migration mapping to *rally.db.migration.versions* After this is done, rally database can be updated via *rally-manage* command. Versions check -------------- Alembic saves currect migration version in table *alembic_version*: .. code-block:: sqlite> .schema alembic_version CREATE TABLE alembic_version ( version_num VARCHAR(32) NOT NULL ); *rally.db.migration* provides a simple mechanism for checking database version - it should compare version from the database with the last version from *rally.db.migration.versions*. This check should be invoked by each rally command, so versioning mismatch will cause error immediately before real action. CLI interface ------------- Pbr-generated tool *rally-manage* provides a cli interface for managing migrations. This requires implementation for: .. code-block:: rally.cmd.manage.DBCommands.version_check rally.cmd.manage.DBCommands.version_update *alembic* CLI should not be available for managing migrations, because: * rally-manage is logical entry point for that * duplication of configuration (alembic requires own .ini file) Alternatives ------------ None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: amaretskiy Milestones ---------- Target Milestone for completion: N/A Dependencies ============ None (*alembic* is already available as dependency of *oslo_db*).

'}, {'number': 65, 'created': '2015-12-17 16:58:00.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/1596c61a0a32c52e0705793e140c82a36b6cb68a', 'message': 'Use install_rally.sh during devstack installation

* With this patch devstack installs Rally into
  virtualenv. It uses Rally setup script to do the job.
* Affected tox.ini cause functional tests need installed
  devstack with rally. Remove extra installation of Rally
  with tox.
* Refactored install_rally.sh: source directory removal
  functional deleted cause user responsibility.

Also tests/ci/rally_verify.py renamed to rally_verify_origin.py
This is caused that infra configured to execute it as a gate job script.
But one does not take care about virtualenv
Therefore, new rally_verify.py is implemented to construct command line
with virtualenv python and rally_verify_origin.py
This is a temporary step to pass gates. When this patch will be merged
infra gate hob config has to be changed and well as
rally_verify_origin.py renamed back.

Change-Id: I1ddb3af53606904dc5c0bca924bc853a488f1f80

'}, {'number': 83, 'created': '2016-02-12 13:57:03.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rally/commit/d3115c38835f64cd0bbd7873504ec94da4aae55e', 'message': 'Use install_rally.sh during devstack installation

* Add option RALLY_IN_VIRTUALENV to devstack plugin
  (defalut False)
* Refactor install_rally.sh: source directory removal
  functional deleted cause user responsibility.
* fix issue with write access to sqlite dataase file
* fix issue with sqlite database file path when the absoute path passed
  as --db-name argument
* update Dockerfile to properly use of install_rally.sh
  install_rally.sh itself calls rally-manage db recreate so there is no
  need to do it explicitly in Dockerfile

commit_message:
Use install_rally.sh during devstack installation

* Add option RALLY_IN_VIRTUALENV to devstack plugin
  (defalut False)
* Refactor install_rally.sh: source directory removal
  functional deleted cause user responsibility.
* fix issue with write access to sqlite dataase file
* fix issue with sqlite database file path when the absoute path passed
  as --db-name argument
* update Dockerfile to properly use of install_rally.sh
  install_rally.sh itself calls rally-manage db recreate so there is no
  need to do it explicitly in Dockerfile

Co-Authored-By: Illia Khudoshyn <ikhudoshyn@mirantis.com>
Change-Id: I1ddb3af53606904dc5c0bca924bc853a488f1f80
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rally refs/changes/37/210137/70 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: RALLY_GIT_REPO=${RALLY_REPO:-${GIT_BASE}/openstack/rally.git} RALLY_GIT_BRANCH=${RALLY_BRANCH:-master}aRALLY_DIR=${RALLY_DEST:-$DEST/rally} RALLY_CONF_FILE=$RALLY_DIR/etc/rally/rally.conf RALLY_BIN_DIR=$RALLY_DIR/bin RALLY_ARGS="-v -y -d $RALLY_DIR --develop" RALLY_TMP_DIR=$(mktmp -d) git_clone $RALLY_GIT_REPO -b $RALLY_GIT_BRANCH $RALLY_TMP_DIR pushd $RALLY_TMP_DIR > /dev/null $RALLY_TMP_DIR/install_rally.sh $RALLY_ARGS popd > /dev/null rm -rf $RALLY_TMP_DIR unset RALLY_TMP_DIR chown -R $STACK_USER $RALLY_DIR } # configure_rally() iniset $RALLY_CONF_FILE DEFAULT debug $RALLY_DEBUG iniset $RALLY_CONF_FILE DEFAULT use_syslog $SYSLOG BENCHMARK_TENANT=$(keystone tenant-create \ --name $BENCHMARK_TENANT \ --tenant-id $BENCHMARK_TENANT function init_rally() { $RALLY_BIN_DIR/rally deployment create --name devstack --filename $tmpfile
deleted_lines: RALLY_REPO=${RALLY_REPO:-${GIT_BASE}/openstack/rally.git} RALLY_BRANCH=${RALLY_BRANCH:-master}RALLY_DIR=$DEST/rally RALLY_CONF_DIR=${RALLY_CONF_DIR:-/etc/rally} RALLY_CONF_FILE=rally.conf# Support entry points installation of console scripts if [[ -d $RALLY_DIR/bin ]]; then RALLY_BIN_DIR=$NOVA_DIR/bin else RALLY_BIN_DIR=$(get_python_exec_prefix) fi git_clone $RALLY_REPO $RALLY_DIR $RALLY_BRANCH setup_develop $RALLY_DIR } # configure_rally() - Set config files, create data dirs, etc if [[ ! -d $RALLY_CONF_DIR ]]; then sudo mkdir -p $RALLY_CONF_DIR fi sudo chown $STACK_USER $RALLY_CONF_DIR # Copy over rally configuration file and configure common parameters. cp $RALLY_DIR/etc/rally/rally.conf.sample $RALLY_CONF_DIR/$RALLY_CONF_FILE iniset $RALLY_CONF_DIR/$RALLY_CONF_FILE DEFAULT debug $RALLY_DEBUG iniset $RALLY_CONF_DIR/$RALLY_CONF_FILE database connection `database_connection_url rally` iniset $RALLY_CONF_DIR/$RALLY_CONF_FILE DEFAULT use_syslog $SYSLOG BENHCMARK_TENANT=$(keystone tenant-create \ --name benchmark \ --tenant-id $BENHCMARK_TENANTfunction init_rally() { recreate_database rally utf8 # Recreate rally database $RALLY_BIN_DIR/rally-manage --config-file $RALLY_CONF_DIR/$RALLY_CONF_FILE db recreate $RALLY_BIN_DIR/rally --config-file $RALLY_CONF_DIR/$RALLY_CONF_FILE deployment create --name devstack --filename $tmpfile

commit_message:
Fix ParameterInput component

* correctly handle comma_delimited_list parameter types
* don't limit minimum value of number type parameters as certain
  parameters require a negative value
* fix HorizontalStaticText value prop

Closes-Bug: 1721520
Change-Id: If1b4138b45b93190f7d03c661d0e90db1e4846c4

commit_message:
Correct descriptions of install doc

1. add create pid step
2. correct service config file name to 'zaqar-uwsgi.service'
3. move zaqar.conf into /etc/zaqar/
4. change uwsgi workdir to path '/srv/zaqar'

Change-Id: I6aafbb3b84abaf3ae40561055c2c122d9a1c8dff
Closes-bug: 1716864

subject: Introduce ironic_dnsmasq_bootfile
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-17 08:43:09.000000000', 'files': ['ansible/roles/ironic/templates/ironic-dnsmasq.conf.j2', 'ansible/roles/ironic/defaults/main.yml'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible/commit/51cffd387bd6f701472e5b89063d3b426b0eb657', 'message': 'Introduce ironic_dnsmasq_bootfile

Currently ironic-dnsmasq set pxelinux.0 as bootfile-name as default.
dhcp-option=option:bootfile-name,pxelinux.0

However it is incrorect on other platform like aarch64, where grubaa64.efi is used.
So introduce ironic_dnsmasq_bootfile, with default value pxelinux.0
And it can be overwritten in globals.yml

/etc/kolla/globals.yml
ironic_dnsmasq_bootfile: "grubaa64.efi"

Change-Id: I9eb95048180f391c08640e9f853a005eb12ceda2
Signed-off-by: Zhangfei Gao <zhangfei.gao@linaro.org>
'}]
commit_message:
Introduce ironic_dnsmasq_bootfile

Currently ironic-dnsmasq set pxelinux.0 as bootfile-name as default.
dhcp-option=option:bootfile-name,pxelinux.0

However it is incrorect on other platform like aarch64, where grubaa64.efi is used.
So introduce ironic_dnsmasq_bootfile, with default value pxelinux.0
And it can be overwritten in globals.yml

/etc/kolla/globals.yml
ironic_dnsmasq_bootfile: "grubaa64.efi"

Change-Id: I9eb95048180f391c08640e9f853a005eb12ceda2
Signed-off-by: Zhangfei Gao <zhangfei.gao@linaro.org>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/kolla-ansible refs/changes/41/512541/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ironic_dnsmasq_bootfile: "pxelinux.0"

commit_message:
Fix requirements cross-test jobs

These were supposed to have the cross-test project name templated
in, but the migration script used the variable which means
"the current project" instead.  That is always openstack-requirements
for these jobs.

Change-Id: I68aba7ca3276814fd6ba84296cc575faaeeeeacd

commit_message:
Don't sleep on exception

Sleeping on exception causes the journal to get stuck in processing
while providing no benefit since the exception is not due to a
connection error.

Change-Id: Id5e7f956ba84f85dfaf901d9148d5d05a6437762
Closes-Bug: #1715082

commit_message:
Fix zanata cert import

The task currently fails with:
"keytool -printcert -rfc -sslserver translate.openstack.org:443:443"
"keytool error: java.lang.Exception: No certificate from the SSL server"

Remove extra :443 to have the keytool command work.

Change-Id: I95e77e72188647d7c9bbf64a7ace82191c4a7853

commit_message:
Rename base.rebuild_server to base.recreate_server

compute.base.rebuild_server is to delete and create
a new server, and the name "rebuild_server" could be
easily taken for servers_client.rebuild_server, so
this is to rename it as recreate_server to distinquish
from servers_client.rebuild_server.

Change-Id: I1589750870dff1a2681192e2f3d151ef18bf4d2a

commit_message:
Add Quobyte policy tag support to Quobyte Cinder driver

This adds support for Quobyte (placement) policies through volume_type extra_specs.
These can be set optionally and if present change the path under which a Cinder
volumes file is stored on the Quobyte volume. Multiple placement policies are
accessible through different volume_types. By applying retype operations a Cinder
volume can be moved from one policy to another.

This change also updates some related comments and improves/corrects
_get_mount_point_for_share() parameter naming.

Implements: blueprint quobyte-placement-policies

Change-Id: I3427460d5145b12f5bc789103a5d58b80bff38f0

commit_message:
Log message

From the following code, session can't be opened when environment
status is DEPLOYING or DELETING status.

if env_status in (states.EnvironmentStatus.DEPLOYING,
                          states.EnvironmentStatus.DELETING):

Change-Id: I4f20b51f87a77cfbf2d76e9961d8bfaa6380aac8

This converts the tox-lint job to zuulv3. There is a standard
openstack-tox-linters that we can rely on.

Change-Id: I31eb188d9bde1fa0db5a46b3fa8b412f729d939e
(cherry picked from commit 8a6a32e1f133b4be41e5aa9bba0b60fc73919a80)
(cherry picked from commit d70c0e53d59acf7eeada4ef32903038b760db5ca)

commit_message:
Fix REFNAME in propose_update.sh

ZUUL_REFNAME is not set in periodic pipelines.

Provide optionally branch and use that one instead if REFNAME is not set
to mimic how the script was used in v2.

Change-Id: I3a514b5ffd9d0797c1bd43a0762bd5709630b1cd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/project-config refs/changes/70/512770/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: BRANCH_NAME=$2 if [ -z "$BRANCH_NAME" ] ; then echo "usage: $0 project branch" exit 1 fi # In periodic pipelines, ZUUL_REFNAME is not set, use BRANCH_NAME # instead here. ZUUL_REFNAME=$BRANCH_NAME

revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-16 20:53:23.000000000', 'files': ['.zuul.yaml', 'tox.ini'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/rpm-packaging/commit/fb24b5ce7077c164946e54292b8779dbb0c1e607', 'message': 'Add zuul.yaml for zuulv3

This converts the tox-lint job to zuulv3. There is a standard
openstack-tox-linters that we can rely on.

Change-Id: I31eb188d9bde1fa0db5a46b3fa8b412f729d939e
(cherry picked from commit 8a6a32e1f133b4be41e5aa9bba0b60fc73919a80)

commit_message:
Add zuul.yaml for zuulv3

This converts the tox-lint job to zuulv3. There is a standard
openstack-tox-linters that we can rely on.

Change-Id: I31eb188d9bde1fa0db5a46b3fa8b412f729d939e
(cherry picked from commit 8a6a32e1f133b4be41e5aa9bba0b60fc73919a80)
(cherry picked from commit d70c0e53d59acf7eeada4ef32903038b760db5ca)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/rpm-packaging refs/changes/19/512419/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: [testenv:linters]# compat. remove me [testenv:lint] commands = {[testenv:linters]commands}

commit_message:
functional tests: ignore all ODL tables

Because some ODL DB consistency checks fail [1], and our purpose is
not to run ODL these checks in this project.

http://logs.openstack.org/13/494213/7/check/legacy-networking-bgpvpn-dsvm-functional/70b8416/job-output.txt.gz#_2017-10-06_18_23_58_755159

Change-Id: I0148b577244b57ea54a58ca3ea00d10249a62d1e
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/networking-bgpvpn refs/changes/44/510444/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ODL_TABLE_PREFIXES = { 'odl_', 'opendaylight'EXTERNAL_TABLES = set(external.TABLES) | BAGPIPE_TABLES name in EXTERNAL_TABLES or any([name.startswith(prefix) for prefix in ODL_TABLE_PREFIXES])):
deleted_lines: ODL_TABLES = { 'odl_alembic_version', 'opendaylightjournal', 'opendaylight_maintenance', EXTERNAL_TABLES = set(external.TABLES) | BAGPIPE_TABLES | ODL_TABLES name in EXTERNAL_TABLES):

subject: enable arp_responder by default for DVR OVS agent
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2017-10-06 12:35:28.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/neutron/commit/857be6c233d8eca7a055b907943584535e3691b8', 'message': "enable arp_responder by default for DVR OVS agent

arp_responder should be enabled by default in DVR installation.
Also when arp_responder is enabled, DVR HA migration tempest scenario
tests are consistently passing(Please see my comments in [1]).
Historically this option was introduced just because we were gating on

commit_message:
enable arp_responder by default for DVR OVS agent

arp_responder should be enabled by default in DVR installation.
Also when arp_responder is enabled, DVR HA migration tempest scenario
tests are consistently passing(Please see my comments in [1]).
Historically this option was introduced just because we were gating on
ubuntu trusty which had ovs 2.0.x and arp responder didn't work there.
With this change, if DVR is enabled for ovs agent then we also enable
arp_responder.

[1] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/500384/

Related-Bug: #1714802
Change-Id: I7c524ff602552d7103197e67421f383ce7d86d42

commit_message:
Initial OSA zuul v3 role jobs

This patch implements an initial set of jobs intended to match
the current job execution method. It does not intend to improve
how the jobs are executed - only to replicate what is currently
in openstack-infra/openstack-zuul-jobs and provide the platform
to iterate on.

Change-Id: Ib5ec32e6f746ae11e8f74453c0232b060516eafe

wrong wwpns send to add_fc_zone and I/O failed.
This patch filter the correct wwpns for add_fc_zone.
